ii. Draw a circuit diagram for Circuit <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

(b) The scientist designs a circuit consisting of a resistor of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, an uncharged capacitor of capacitance <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, a switch, and a battery with potential difference <math alttext="epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math> connected in series.i. Derive an expression for the current <math alttext="uppercase I sub R comma lowercase i, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> in the resistor immediately after the switch is closed. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

ii. Determine an expression for the current <math alttext="uppercase I sub R comma f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> in the resistor after the switch has been closed for a very long time.

(c) On the grids in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, sketch the current <math alttext="uppercase I sub R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>R</mtext></msub></math> in the resistor and the potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> across the capacitor as functions of time for the circuit in part (b). Label any intercepts and/or asymptotes in terms of given quantities.

(d) The scientist modifies the circuit from part (b) by adding a second identical resistor in series with the other circuit components. Indicate how the current <math alttext="uppercase I sub R comma lowercase i, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> in the resistor immediately after the switch is closed compares to that in the circuit from part (b). Briefly justify your answer.
